Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Polidocanol Foam Sclerotherapy vs. Conventional Surgery for Varicose Veins

Trial_Design.evidence: Sample size calculation aimed to detect a 1.5-point difference in VCSS with 80% power and 95% confidence.

Participants.evidence: 205 patients were recruited from two public health institutions in São Paulo, Brazil

Intervention.evidence: Participants were non-randomly assigned to PFS (57 patients, 90 legs) or CS (148 patients, 236 legs).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the effectiveness of polidocanol foam sclerotherapy (PFS) compared to conventional surgery (CS) for treating lower limb varicose veins, focusing on Patient-Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in Venous Clinical Severity Score (VCSS) and VEINES-QoL/Sym scores, measured preoperatively and 30 days post-treatment.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were non-randomly assigned to PFS (57 patients, 90 legs) or CS (148 patients, 236 legs).

Blinding.evidence: The study was not randomised, and no blinding was used.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 205 patients were recruited from two public health institutions in São Paulo, Brazil, between October 2021 and October 2022.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were non-randomly assigned to PFS (57 patients, 90 legs) or CS (148 patients, 236 legs).

Result_Outcome.evidence: CS demonstrated greater improvements in VCSS (mean difference = 4.02, 95% CI 3.1 to 5.0; p < 0.001), VEINES-QoL (mean difference = 8, 95% CI 6.5 to 9.5; p < 0.001), and VEINES-Sym (mean difference = 11.66, 95% CI 9.8 to 13.5; p < 0.001) compared to PFS.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
